channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: What We Know About the Gun Battle With Cuban Border Troops
item.description: Four armed Cuban nationals aboard a Florida-based speedboat died in a gunfight with border troops near the island nation’s coast, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei, Frances Robles, Jack Nicas, Eric Schmitt and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Cuban Coast Guard ships docked at the port of Havana on Wednesday.

item.title: For Trump, Military Strike in Iran Could Serve Symbolic Purpose
item.description: Some officials in the Trump administration hope an attack would force Iran to give up its nuclear enrichment program. Others have doubts.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Helene Cooper
item.media:description: American fighter jets on the aircraft carrier Gerald R. Ford off the coast of Greece. The U.S. military is amassing firepower in the region near Iran.

item.title: Trump Administration Withholds $259 Million in Medicaid Funds From Minnesota
item.description: Vice President JD Vance said that the Trump administration had been forced to “turn the screws on” Minnesota so the state would respond to allegations of fraud.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:description: Vice President JD Vance at the White House on Wednesday.

item.title: Patel Fires F.B.I. Personnel Tied to Inquiry Into Trump and Classified Records
item.description: The firings are part of a rolling barrage of retribution aimed at those who worked on the two federal prosecutions of President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Alan Feuer and Devlin Barrett
item.category: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (Documents Case)
item.media:credit: Pete Kiehart for The New York Times
item.media:description: The F.B.I. building in Washington, D.C. The firings came hours after Kash Patel, the F.B.I. director, said that as part of the documents inquiry, the bureau had subpoenaed phone metadata for himself and Susie Wiles, currently the White House chief of staff.

item.title: Police Officer Accused of Tracking Partner Using License Plate Reader
item.description: The Milwaukee officer used the technology to run searches on his partner’s plate 124 times, officials said, and he also tracked the person’s ex.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler
item.media:description: If convicted on the misdemeanor charge, attempted misconduct in public office, the officer could face up to nine months in prison and a $10,000 fine.

item.title: An Inside Look at the State of the Union
item.description: Our photojournalist Kenny Holston was the only news photographer on the House floor during President Trump’s State of the Union speech. Here’s how he captured his images.
item.dc:creator: Kenny Holston, Sutton Raphael, Mac Schneider and Nikolay Nikolov

item.title: Ilhan Omar Condemns Guest’s Arrest at Trump’s State of the Union
item.description: Aliya Rahman, a U.S. citizen who was dragged from her vehicle after an ICE agent shattered its window, was charged with unlawful conduct after standing up during President Trump’s speech.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron and Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Ilhan Omar, Democrat of Minnesota, at the State of the Union address yesterday.

item.title: How Social Media Framed Trump’s State of the Union Speech
item.description: Here’s how social media may have shaped your impressions of the State of the Union.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:description: President Trump giving his State of the Union address.

item.title: Trump’s Push for Election Power Raises Fears He Will ‘Subvert’ Midterms
item.description: The president appears to be undermining Americans’ faith in the outcome, at a moment when Republicans face an uphill climb to keep control of Congress.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:description: During his State of the Union address on Tuesday, President Trump suggested that “it should be my third term” and falsely declared that the “only way” that Democrats “can get elected is to cheat.”

item.title: Trump Officials Seek to Break Editorial ‘Firewall’ at U.S.-Funded News Agencies
item.description: Two federally funded newsrooms received a draft funding agreement that could give President Trump’s appointees the power to veto their new hires for editors in chief and chief executives.
item.dc:creator: Minho Kim
item.media:description: Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty and Middle East Broadcasting Networks received a draft funding agreement that could give President Trump’s political appointees more control over their operations.

item.title: Judge Finds Trump Administration’s Third-Country Deportations Unlawful
item.description: The ruling repudiates a key Homeland Security Department policy of sending immigrants to countries where they have no ties. The judge paused his ruling to allow for an appeal.
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of Middle Eastern and Asian migrants deported by the U.S. government at a shelter in Panama City last year.

item.title: Senate Votes to Fill Seat of Air Safety Official Ousted by Trump
item.description: John DeLeeuw, an American Airlines executive, was confirmed to the seat vacated by Alvin Brown, who is suing over his ouster.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Alex Kent for The New York Times
item.media:description: John DeLeeuw’s confirmation to the National Transportation Safety Board fills an opening that President Trump created when he fired the board’s vice chair.

item.title: For America’s 250th, Should the Coin of Trump’s Realm Be Gold?
item.description: A federally appointed committee is pushing back on plans to mint gold currency depicting President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Dan Barry

item.title: Trump’s speech gets a mixed reaction around the world.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:description: President Trump delivering his State of the Union address in Washington on Tuesday.

item.title: Casey Means, Surgeon General Nominee, Sidesteps Questions on Vaccines at Senate Hearing
item.description: Dr. Casey Means, a wellness influencer, author and supporter of Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., said that “anti-vaccine rhetoric has never been part” of her message.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Alex Kent for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Our nation is angry, exhausted and hurting from preventable diseases,” Dr. Casey Means told the Senate Health Committee on Wednesday.

item.title: As More Products and Places Bear His Name, Trump Plays Coy
item.description: In his State of the Union address, President Trump promoted two programs that just so happened to be named after him.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:description: President Trump at an event to unveil the TrumpRx discount drug website earlier this month.

item.title: Former Nebraska Sen. Bob Kerrey Resigns From Monolith Amid Epstein Emails
item.description: Mr. Kerrey has left his role as chairman of the company, Monolith, after Justice Department documents showed he had met and corresponded with Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Sonia A. Rao
item.media:description: Bob Kerrey speaking in Omaha in 2012.

item.title: F.B.I. Raids Home and Office of L.A.U.S.D. Chief Alberto Carvalho
item.description: The investigation appears to be related to a $6 million contract the district had with a tech start-up whose staff had ties to the superintendent, Alberto Carvalho.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler, Dana Goldstein and Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: The F.B.I. raided the home of Alberto M. Carvalho, superintendent of the Los Angeles Unified School District, and the district offices on Wednesday.

item.title: 7 Voters React to Trump’s State of the Union Speech
item.description: With his job approval ratings ticking down, President Trump said that his second term so far was “a turnaround for the ages.” Did he persuade voters?
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson, Ruth Igielnik, Christina Morales and Chris Hippensteel

item.title: Texas Gov. Greg Abbott Spent Millions on Attack Ads Against Jasmine Crockett
item.description: Gov. Greg Abbott hopes the ads featuring the Democrat will galvanize Republican voter turnout in November.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman
item.media:description: Representative Jasmine Crockett during a House Judiciary Committee hearing last month.

item.title: In N.C. Senate Race, Democrats Bet Roy Cooper Can Beat Trump’s Endorsement
item.description: The race is one of a handful of competitive Senate elections this year, but Democrats seem most confident about North Carolina, partly because their candidate, former Gov. Roy Cooper, has never been beaten.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times; Haiyun Jiang, via The New York Times

item.title: Epstein Files Are Missing Records About Woman Who Made Claim Against Trump
item.description: Documents released by the Justice Department briefly mention a woman’s unverified accusation that Donald J. Trump assaulted her in the 1980s, when she was a minor. But several memos related to her account are not in the files.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker and Michael Gold
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: When the Justice Department made files public late last month, officials said it included all material sent by the public to the F.B.I.

item.title: Larry Summers Will Resign From Harvard After Jeffrey Epstein Revelations
item.description: Mr. Summers, former president of the school, had stepped back from teaching after documents showed a closer relationship to Jeffrey Epstein than previously known. He will leave at the end of the academic year.
item.dc:creator: Mark Arsenault
item.media:credit: David Degner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lawrence Summers discussed relationships with Jeffrey Epstein in a correspondence that lasted for years, documents show.

item.title: Ex-Head of San Francisco Homeless Nonprofit Is Charged With Misusing Over $1 Million
item.description: Gwendolyn Westbrook, who led the United Council of Human Services, misappropriated public funds for her own use, prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Jessica Christian/San Francisco Chronicle, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Gwendolyn Westbrook received an award from Mayor London Breed of San Francisco in 2021.

item.title: With Epstein Deposition, Hillary Clinton Is Again Answering for Bill Clinton’s Actions
item.description: The former first lady, senator and secretary of state had no dealings with Jeffrey Epstein but is once again under pressure to answer for the actions and relationships of her husband.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:description: Hillary Clinton with President Bill Clinton in December 1998, after he was impeached by the House of Representatives.

item.title: U.S. and Ukrainian officials to meet in Geneva this week.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier in Kostiantynivka last month.

item.title: Democrats counter Trump after his combative State of the Union address.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater, Carl Hulse, Shawn McCreesh and Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Rashida Tlaib, center, Democrat of Michigan, during President Trump’s address.

item.title: How Trump’s Economic Pitch at the State of the Union Echoes Biden’s
item.description: With the midterms approaching and polls showing unease about the economy, some of President Trump’s arguments about its strength sounded eerily like those of his predecessor.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times

item.title: Online Accusations in Guthrie Abduction Leave One Family ‘Scared Numb’
item.description: A fifth-grade teacher and his principal wife hid in their bedroom as dozens of people who believed he might be a kidnapper appeared on their suburban street.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:credit: Cassidy Araiza for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I feel like someone’s taken my name,” said Dominic Evans, who had met Nancy Guthrie only once.

item.title: Trump Puts On a Show, Casting Democrats as the Villains
item.description: On the defensive over the economy and with the midterms approaching, President Trump made clear that his political strategy is to paint Democrats as unpatriotic and ‘crazy.’
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
